message.content: This question tests knowledge about the capabilities of a seismometer. A seismometer is a device used to measure and record seismic waves generated by earthquakes. It can detect the strength of an earthquake by measuring the amplitude of the ground motion. Option (A) is incorrect because a seismometer does not determine the size of an earthquake, but rather the strength. Option (B) is incorrect because the speed of an earthquake is not measured by a seismometer, but rather the intensity. Option (D) is incorrect because a seismometer does not measure the duration of an earthquake, but rather the magnitude.

This question requires basic knowledge about seismometers and their ability to measure and record seismic activity. A seismometer measures the strength or magnitude of an earthquake, not its size, speed, or duration. Option (C) is correct because seismometers can detect and record the strength or intensity of an earthquake. Options (A), (B), and (D) are not related to the function of a seismometer.

This question requires knowledge about seismometers and their function. Seismometers are instruments used to measure and record the intensity or strength of earthquakes. Therefore, seismometers can note how strong an earthquake is, making option (C) the correct answer. Options (A), (B), and (D) are not relevant to the capabilities of a seismometer.
